repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
The name was misleading and caused bugs. After fixing these bugs (#25111, #25115), there are no more usages of `for_each_child`.

Since the function is technically part of the external API, I've opted not to outright remove it yet.

In the future, if we want to restore this functionality, we can add to `shared.lua` something like (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25109#discussion_r1322907970):

```lua
--- Visits children of a node recursively, applying the provided visitor function
---@generic Node: table
---@param node Node The root node to visit
---@param visitor fun(node: Node): boolean|nil Function to call at each node.
---       If it returns true, it will skip recursing into the children of the node.
---@param key nil|string|fun(node: Node): Node[] How to find the children of a node. default: "children"
function vim.traverse(node, visitor, key)
  if not visitor(node) then
    local children = node.children
    if type(key) == 'function' then
      children = key(node)
    elseif key then
      children = node[key]
    end
    for _, child in pairs(children or {}) do
      vim.traverse(child, visitor, key)
    end
  end
end
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -451,11 +451,14 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
   return self._trees
 end
 
+---@deprecated Misleading name. If you don't want recursion, use `LanguageTree:children`;
+---            if you do, do it yourself.
 --- Invokes the callback for each |LanguageTree| and its children recursively
 ---
 ---@param fn fun(tree: LanguageTree, lang: string)
 ---@param include_self boolean|nil Whether to include the invoking tree in the results
 function LanguageTree:for_each_child(fn, include_self)
+  vim.deprecate('LanguageTree:for_each_child()', 'LanguageTree:children()', '0.10')

comment_regular_data.body: imo we should slap a `vim.deprecate()` in here too. treesitter support is still considered unstable, and this function was always questionable.
Sure, updated.

`_children` is a private field so this PR means there would be no supported way (other than `for_each_tree`) of recursing.

I also don't won't to expose `_children` as the shape of this might change in the future.
There's `TSNode:child_count()` and `TSNode:child({index})`, though.
That's not for the languagetree, they are native TS objects.

> _children is a private field

Seems like the easy fix for this would just be to add a getter. `LanguageTree:children()`. Should I do that?

> That's not for the languagetree, they are native TS objects.

Yes? The code snippet in the PR description works on TSNodes, does it not?

> Yes? The code snippet in the PR description works on TSNodes, does it not?

I think what he's saying is for `LanguageTree` specifically (`LanguageTree` != `TSNode` IIRC) he doesn't want users calling `vim.traverse(tree, visitor, "_children")`. To which I responded above
OK, but `LanguageTree:children()` already exists?

> > That's not for the languagetree, they are native TS objects.
> 
> Yes? The code snippet in the PR description works on TSNodes, does it not?

It would but doesn't mean it can replace `for_each_child`.

> OK, but `LanguageTree:children()` already exists?

You're right, it does ðŸ˜‚
(unless someone wants to deprecate that, too... "Nice API you got there. Would be a shame if someone were to... deprecate it.")

> It would but doesn't mean it can replace for_each_child.

`vim.traverse(language_tree, visitor, function(node) return node:children() end)`

Although tbh even without `vim.traverse` it literally is like 3 extra lines to add recursion to a function.

> > _children is a private field
> 
> Seems like the easy fix for this would just be to add a getter. `LanguageTree:children()`. Should I do that?

Until we've settled on the internal structure I'd prefer to keep changes to the API to an absolute minimum as to avoid breakages and churn for downstream users.

Once incremental parsing works properly and we implement async parsing, we can start designing out the API more.

> Until we've settled on the internal structure I'd prefer to keep changes to the API to an absolute minimum as to avoid breakages and churn for downstream users.

Turns out the cat is already out of the bag on this one:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/bc67cf3ccdf935a0e2974fbbe5557a3d24931c54/runtime/doc/treesitter.txt#L1077

`LanguageTree:children()` was added in 2020 as part of the original `LanguageTree` definition and has been around ever since: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/1a631026a942b3311adec0bee6d9b0b932c5de31

Given that, there's no API changes necessary besides the deprecation notice. Which I've just updated to recommend `LanguageTree:children()`
I would personally avoid using `vim.deprecate` here. All it's practically going to do is disrupt users and gives 0 time for plugins to adapt.

Github search shows no hits for `for_each_child language:lua`. Maybe we could risk it and revert (with a better idea of the usage) if someone complains? 

(In general, I agree about being conservative with `vim.deprecate` about low-level API functions that are likely run in a loop.)
Ok I guess. ðŸ¤·

> Github search shows no hits for `for_each_child language:lua`.

Well I found 137 Files with that search

edit: seems like most of them are from neovim, neorg, nvim-ts/playground and nvim-ts-rainbow

> Well I found 137 Files with that search
> 
> edit: seems like most of them are from neovim, neorg, nvim-ts/playground and nvim-ts-rainbow

Yeah, I'm getting a notification from `rainbow-delimiters`. It doesn't look that bad, only shows up once.

I'm down to back off the `vim.deprecate`, or rather, I'm indifferent.

Also, if it eases the transition for users, I can go ahead and put in `vim.traverse` in this PR.

Let's go ahead and try this. `vim.deprecate` only shows messages once (`notify_once`) so I don't see why it's a problem.

- I think this needs a news.txt update though: a new item in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4607807f9fcb83d4e183f6f67e705ffd7f451077/runtime/doc/news.txt#L244
- `vim.traverse` should be a separate PR to gather comments. BTW the callback arg should always be last, if possible.
needs a `news.txt` entry, which could have a short snippet illustrating the `pairs(node:children())` replacement.

Yeah the notification UX wasn't an issue for me :+1: I'm sure people (e.g. me) will just file issues/PRs with plugins.

Just updated `news.txt`. I kept it terse since I'm sure people can figure out how to use `LanguageTree:children()`.

labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(languagetree): deprecate `for_each_child`
